newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan plans tax reform to boost investment.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan plans tax reform to boost investment.

text.p: Taiwan's Finance Ministry announced a "two-into-one" tax merger on Wednesday to boost investment and a slowing economy.
Finance Minister Paul Chiu said the ministry would merge the island's two income taxes into one business income tax of 25 percent.

The merger would cut tax revenues by about T$26.8 billion (US$975 million) a year, but the ministry would recoup the loss by assessing a 10 percent levy on profits that enterprises reserve rather than distribute to shareholders immediately, Chiu said.
"The new tax system will avoid double taxation and will help corporate structures," Chiu told reporters.
"In fact, this is a tax reduction," Chiu said. "It will encourage investment (in Taiwan) and increase our international competitiveness."
Taiwan has been wooing multinationals to establish the island as a regional hub for Asia-Pacific operations by boosting local economic competitiveness.
The tax reform needed parliamentary approval and could take effect in 1998, the minister said.
Foreign nationals' taxes were not affected because their maximum rate would remain the same at 40 percent, Chiu said.
What the ministry has called a "two-into-one" tax merger is an accounting change that eliminates double taxation of companies' profits and the dividends they pay to shareholders.
Maximum assessments on domestic individuals' income will be capped at 40 percent, compared with the maximum 55 percent before the merger.
Currently, foreign investors' income is taxed first by a 25 percent business income tax, and then a 20 percent dividend tax on the 75 percent untaxed part, making the rate 40 percent.
Economists said the tax reform would only encourage domestic investment, not foreign investment.
"Such a tax reduction reform will surely boost domestic investment," said Sun Ke-nan, a panel member from the prestigious Chunghua Institution for Economic Research.
"But we don't see any improvement on how to encourge foreign investment in the proposal," he said.
"In order to develop Taiwan into an Asia-Pacific financial centre, we may consider lowering the dividend tax on foreign investors to 15 percent from the current 20 percent," Sun said.
Foreign investors said they wanted more.

"The tax reform really doesn't benefit foreign corporations at all, because foreign investors still have to pay 20 percent in dividend tax, and that dampens investment interest a great deal," said Ken Sien, a partner at Price Waterhouse.
"The dividend tax tilts the playing field against foreigners. Taiwan must cancel that tax...if it really wants to become an Asia-Pacific financial centre," Sien said.

Sun said the planned levy of 10 percent on enterprises' reserved profits would discourage high-tech investments as they now enjoyed tax-free treatment of reserved profits of up to 200 percent of capitalisation.
